texts.definition: The characteristic of a game that it is difficult to reliably determine what the final outcome of a game instance will be before gameplay begins.
markups: <style="Definition">The characteristic of a game that it is difficult to reliably determine what the final outcome of a game instance will be before gameplay begins.</style>

A central part of gameplay experiences is that players do not know what the final outcome will be; this is what lets players feel that they have a possibility to affect the outcome or let them pick an outcome that wish will occur. Having an <style="CurrentLink">Uncertainty of Outcome</style> each time the game is played is the requirement for this.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Gambling%20Games">Gambling Games</link></style>, for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Blackjack">Blackjack</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guts">Guts</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Roulette">Roulette</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Texas%20Hold'em">Texas Hold'em</link></style>, rely on heavily on uncertainty that comes from a combination of randomness and unpredictability of what other players will do. They share the latter with perfect information games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> but here the unpredictability of other players depend on the difficulty of being able to calculate the full consequences of the actions possible.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Sports">Sports</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bowling">Bowling</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Figure%20Skating">Figure Skating</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Soccer">Soccer</link></style>, have <style="CurrentLink">Uncertainty of Outcome</style> because players can perform actions with varying levels of success. This is also found in computer-based <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Real-Time%20Games">Real-Time Games</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike%20series">Counter-Strike series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/League%20of%20Legends">League of Legends</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pong">Pong</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Uncertainty of Outcome</style> is very often a design goal in games since it provides a basic <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> to gameplay. Being more a consequence of more specific rule design than a characteristics directly appearing through rules, it is typically made present in a game through specific subpatterns. Third main sources for <style="CurrentLink">Uncertainty of Outcome</style> can be pointed out. First, uncertainty can simply come from <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>. Second, the complexity of the game state or game system can give players <style="Link"><link="solution-uncertainty">Solution Uncertainty</link></style>. Thirdly, uncertainty can come from the players themselves or other <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> in a game through <style="Link"><link="performance-uncertainty">Performance Uncertainty</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-unpredictability">Player Unpredictability</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="unpredictable-behavior">Unpredictable Behavior</link></style>. As a more specific case, <style="Link"><link="end-state-scoring">End State Scoring</link></style> can cause <style="CurrentLink">Uncertainty of Outcome</style> not only from the means above, but also because not all factors related to the scoring may have been set until the end of gameplay.

There are some other reasons why <style="CurrentLink">Uncertainty of Outcome</style> can be a design goal in a game. One such reasons is to either make <style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style> possible or to make it interesting, another to have a basic foundation for <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style>. A variant of <style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="bidding">Bidding</link></style>, instead has uncertainty from players typically not knowing how much other players are willing to bid.

As stated above, <style="CurrentLink">Uncertainty of Outcome</style> typically adds <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> to games, and in many cases provide <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style> as well. It works directly against <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominant%20Strategies">Dominant Strategies</link></style> and through this also against a <style="Link"><link="predictable-winner">Predictable Winner</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="kingmaker">Kingmaker</link></style>. It can make players with <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> be less likely to win but still let them have an advantage based upon their expertise.

<style="Link"><link="bidding">Bidding</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="end-state-scoring">End State Scoring</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="performance-uncertainty">Performance Uncertainty</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-unpredictability">Player Unpredictability</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="solution-uncertainty">Solution Uncertainty</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="unpredictable-behavior">Unpredictable Behavior</link></style>
